{{No footnotes|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = YP Midwest Publishing LLC.| logo = | type = Private (Subsidiary of [[YP Holdings]])| foundation = 1983| location = [[Tucker, Georgia]], United States| industry = [[Telephone directory|Directory Publishing]]| products = [[YP Holdings|YP Real Yellow Pages]] in [[Indiana]], [[Michigan]], [[Ohio]], [[Wisconsin]]| parent = [[Ameritech]] (1983-1999)
[[SBC Communications|SBC/AT&T]] (1999-2012)
[[YP Holdings]] (2012-present)| homepage = }} '''YP Midwest Publishing LLC.''', originally '''Ameritech Publishing, Inc.''', was formed in 1983 during the [[Bell System Divestiture]]. It combined the former directory operations of [[Illinois Bell]], [[Indiana Bell]], [[Michigan Bell]], [[Ohio Bell]] and [[Wisconsin Telephone]]. Ameritech Publishing published telephone directories in Indiana, Ohio, Michigan, and Wisconsin. Directories in [[Illinois]] were made in a joint venture with [[R. H. Donnelley]]. Prior to brand standardization by [[SBC Communications]], Ameritech directories were published under the '''PagesPlus''' brand. Ameritech Publishing's operations in Illinois and northwest Indiana were placed in a partnership with [[R. H. Donnelley]], called '''DonTech''', in 1999. Following brand standardization since 2002, Ameritech Publishing, the company, is currently known as '''Ameritech Publishing, Inc. d/b/a AT&T Advertising & Publishing'''. ==Spinoff== In 2012, Ameritech Publishing (along with the rest of AT&T Advertising Solutions) was spun off into [[YP Holdings]]. Ameritech Publishing was then renamed '''YP Midwest Publishing LLC.''' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.sfu.ca/~anthonyc/cmpt301/301_case_files/am/ameritech.pdf 1990 Profile of Ameritech Publishing] {{Telephone directory publishers in the United States}} {{Cerberus Capital Management}} [[Category:AT&T subsidiaries]] [[Category:Publishing companies established in 1983]] [[Category:Telephone directory publishing companies of the United States]] [[Category:YP Holdings]] [[Category:1983 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:Companies based in Tucker, Georgia]] {{US-publish-company-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox museum | name = The '''Angelitos Athena''' | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_upright = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = Perserschutt.gif | image_upright = | alt = | caption = [[Perserschutt]] 1866, ''Angelitos-Athena'' (left), [[Moschophoros]] (centre), [[Kritios boy]] (right) | map_type = | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord}} --> | former_name = | established = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} -->480-470 BC | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | location = | type = | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = | visitors = | founder = | executive_director = | leader_type = | leader = | director = | president = | ceo = | chairperson = | curator = | architect = | historian = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | embedded = }} The '''Angelitos Athena''' is an ancient marble statue, which was made around 480-470 BC. The figure, the earliest known depiction of the armed [[Athena]], is an example of the [[severe style]], the transitional style between archaic and classical Greek sculpture which developed after the [[Persian Wars]]. Today it is located at the [[Acropolis Museum]] under the inventory number 140.<ref name=Guide>Dimitrios Pandermalis, Stamatia Eleftheratou, Christina Vlassopoulou, 2014, ''Acropolis Museum: Guide'', p.180</ref>
The statue is heavily damaged and has lost its head. Like earlier depictions of Athena she wears the archaic [[peplos]], but she also has the [[aegis]] over her shoulders, with a [[gorgoneion]] in the centre of her chest. Her upraised right arm survives up to the wrist and once held a spear. Her left arm is entirely missing except for the shoulder and traces of her left hand resting on her waist.
The statue is believed, not completely uncontroversially, to have stood atop a preserved [[doric column]] which reads:<ref name=Guide /> {{Quote|Angelitos dedicated me. Venerable Athena, may this gift be pleasing to you. [[Euenor (sculptor)|Euenor]] made it}} It was found under the [[Perserschutt]] on the [[Akropolis]] in [[Athens]], near the [[Kritios boy]] and the [[Moscophoros]].
==References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://viamus.uni-goettingen.de/pages/imageView/big?Object.Id:record:int=4783 Image] * [http://www.goddess-athena.org/Museum/Sculptures/Alone/Athena_Euenor_x.htm Colour image]
[[Category:Archaeological discoveries in Greece]] [[Category:Acropolis Museum]] [[Category:Marble sculptures in Greece]] [[Category:5th-century BC Greek sculptures]] [[Category:Sculptures in Athens]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Use Australian English|date=December 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} [[File:Australian Poultry Standard.jpg|thumb|right|The cover of the 1998 first edition]]
The '''''Australian Poultry Standards''''' is the official [[breed standard]] for [[poultry]] [[Animal fancy|fancy]] in [[Australia]]. It is the standard of perfection from which all poultry in Australia is supposed to be judged when exhibited at [[poultry show]]s. It is published by Victorian Poultry Fanciers Association, the [[peak body]] for poultry in [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]] and agreed to by all other state peak bodies.
==Publication== Published by the Victorian Poultry Fanciers Association Inc., the first edition of the ''Australian Poultry Standard'' was published in 1998.<ref>{{Citation | author1=Bishop, James | author2=Victorian Poultry Fanciers Association | title=Australian poultry standards : complete descriptions and judging points for all standardised breeds and varieties of domestic poultry in the Commonwealth of Australia | publication-date=1998 | publisher=Victorian Poultry Fanciers' Association Inc | edition=1st | isbn=978-0-646-36231-1 }}</ref> It has been replaced by the second edition.<ref>{{Citation | author1=Victorian Poultry Fanciers Association | author2=Poultry Stud Breeders and Exhibitors Victoria | title=Australian poultry standards | publication-date=2011 | publisher=Victorian Poultry Fanciers Association Limited | edition=2nd | isbn=978-1-921488-23-8 }}</ref><ref>or a pictorial list of the chicken breeds listed in the Australian Poultry Standard 2nd Edition, see the [http://www.backyardpoultry.com/wiki/index.php/Chicken_Breeds_Chart Backyard Poultry Chicken Breeds Chart]</ref>
Australia has no national peak body for poultry, relying on state bodies and national [[breed club]]s. The state bodies who are party to the standards are as follows (None of the mainland territories have a statewide poultry society)
*Victorian Poultry Fanciers Association (trades as Poultry Stud Breeders and Exhibitors Victoria) (founded 1970) *Tasmanian Poultry Fanciers Association *South Australian Poultry Association *Exhibition Poultry Association of New South Wales *Western Australian Poultry Association (founded 1889) *Feather Clubs Association of Queensland (founded 1959)
==Classification of breeds== The ''Australian Poultry Standard'' classifies all chicken breeds as either hard feather or soft feather, and then further divides them into the [[Bantam (poultry)|bantam]] or standard size. Breeds which have less under fluff and feathers which are closer to the body fall under hard feather, such as the [[Old English Game]] and [[Asil (chicken)|Asil]]. Breeds with more under fluff and softer feathers, such as the [[Silkie]], [[Australorp]] and [[Leghorn (chicken)|Leghorn]], are classed as soft feather.
The ''Australian Poultry Standards'' also includes standards for ducks, geese, turkeys and Guinea fowl. Ducks are divided into two classes, bantam or standard size, and all [[domestic turkey|turkey]]s, [[geese]] and [[guinea fowl]] have only one class each.
==Earlier publications== [[File:Points of Fowl with Key.JPG|right|thumb|Hadlingtons' ''Points of Fowl'' from the 1940s]] In the 1940s and earlier, other publications in Australia about poultry, such as Hadlingtons,<ref>{{Citation | author1=Hadlington, James | title=Hadlington's Australian poultry book | publication-date=1943 | publisher=Angus & Robertson | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/12957607 | accessdate=6 December 2013 }}</ref> did have some parts devoted to aspects of showing birds, were less oriented towards show standards, and more detailed about general management of poultry, in line with his earliest publication.<ref>{{Citation | author1=Hadlington, James | author2=New South Wales. Dept. of Agriculture | title=Poultry farming in New South Wales | publication-date=1917 | publisher=W.A. Gullick, Govt. Printer | edition=2nd and rev. | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/17865449 | accessdate=6 December 2013 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of breeds in the Australian Poultry Standards]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{cite web|url=http://www.psbev.com.au/australianpoultrystandards.aspx |publisher=Poultry Stud Breeders & Exhibitors Victoria |title=Poultry Standards - The Australian Poultry Standard |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140809054800/http://www.psbev.com.au/australianpoultrystandards.aspx |archivedate=9 August 2014 |df=dmy }}
[[Category:Handbooks and manuals]] [[Category:Animal breeding standards]] [[Category:Poultry standards]] [[Category:Australian standards]]

revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=January 2008}} {{Infobox professional wrestler | name = Billy Darnell | names = {{Plainlist| * Billy Darnell * Billy Rogers }} | image = Billy Darnell.jpg | caption = | height = | weight = | real_height = | real_weight = | birth_date = {{birth date|1926|2|25|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Camden, New Jersey]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2007|9|7|1926|2|25}} | death_place = [[Maple Shade Township, New Jersey]] | resides = | billed = | trainer = | debut = 1942 | retired = 1961 }} '''Billy Darnell''' (February 25, 1926 – September 7, 2007) was an American [[professional wrestler]] and major star of the 1940s and 1950s, with his career spanning over twenty years with championships in the [[National Wrestling Alliance]] and [[World Wide Wrestling Federation]].<ref name="slam">{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2007/09/08/4480688.html|title=Billy Darnell was a consummate fan favourite|author=Steven Johnson|accessdate=2008-01-30|publisher=SLAM! Sports}}</ref>
==Early life== Darnell was born in [[Camden, New Jersey]]. At age 16, while working as a lifeguard in [[Wildwood, New Jersey]], he was playfighting with co-workers when a [[wrestling promoter]] spotted him and asked him to help with his roster, as many current ones were seeing action in [[World War II]].<ref name="slam"/>
==Career== His first match with later rival [[Buddy Rogers (wrestler)|Buddy Rogers]] was in February 1944, tagging with him in [[Philadelphia]] and [[Baltimore-Washington]]. Darnell would himself leave wrestling for World War II service in December 1944, joining the [[United States Army]].<ref name="slam"/> [[Post-war]] Darnell returned to wrestling in [[Texas]], once more with Rogers, who had previously wrestled under his real name Herman Rohde. At the time he was becoming "Nature Boy" Buddy Rogers, and Darnell was booked as his brother Billy Rogers. This was largely in part to promoter and Rogers' booker [[Jack Pfefer]], though Darnell himself has stated he wasn't sure if the idea for the brother gimmick was Rogers' or Pfefer's.<ref name="slam"/>
Darnell and Rogers next went to [[California]], with wrestling reaching new popularity thanks to [[television]] exposure. For the showmanship of it Rogers donned [[sequin]]ed capes, whereas Darnell first donned the [[leopard]]-skin outfit, for which he would become famous. Their careers would become forever intertwined when they began facing each other with Rogers as the [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heel]] champion and Darnell becoming a heavy fan favorite. Promoters nationwide wanted the Rogers-Darnell match, with more than 200 matches occurring between them. Despite their history Rogers still crushed discs in Darnell's neck with a [[Botch (professional wrestling)|botched]] [[piledriver (professional wrestling)|piledriver]], though he himself accidentally knocked out some of Rogers' teeth. [[Les Thatcher]] has even stated that Darnell's matches with Rogers inspired him to enter the wrestling business.
Darnell was also known for a well recognized team with [[Bill Melby]], winning the [[Chicago]] version of the [[NWA World Tag Team Championship]] with him in 1953.<ref name="JohnsonOliver2012">{{cite book|author1=Steven Johnson|author2=Greg Oliver|author3=Mike Mooneyham|author4=J. J. Dillon|title=The Pro Wrestling Hall of Fame: Heroes and Icons|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0wxLpfRhZqcC&pg=PT344|date=1 October 2012|publisher=ECW Press|isbn=978-1-77090-269-5|pages=344‚Äì}}</ref> In 1954, he worked with [[Sam Muchnick]] in [[St. Louis]] and also booked for an Indiana promotion. In a televised match on 20 May 1961, Darnell beat Ali Pasha (Alexander Vieira Fontes) who died of a heart attack after being slammed down.<ref name="JohnsonOliver2012"/>
He used his World War II [[G.I. Bill]] to attend [[aviation]] school and become a [[Aviator|pilot]], flying himself to his matches. He also ran a [[nightclub]] until 1985. Though Darnell retired in 1961, he would wrestle sparsely into the next year, then went to a [[chiropractic]] school in [[Glendale, California]], finishing in Indiana. He would begin practicing in his home of New Jersey and moved to [[Florida]] for a period, getting back in touch with Rogers, before returning to New Jersey. Darnell regularly attended [[Cauliflower Alley Club]] reunions and received the [[Senator Hugh Farley Award]] from the [[Amsterdam, New York]]-based [[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]].<ref name="slam"/> Darnell died on September 7, 2007 at his home in [[Maple Shade Township, New Jersey]].<ref name="slam"/>
==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[Cauliflower Alley Club]]''' **Other honoree ([[Cauliflower Alley Club#2004|2004]]) *'''[[National Wrestling Alliance]]''' **NWA World Tag Team Championship (Chicago & Indianapolis version) (2 times) - with Bill Melby <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/il/nwa/il-nwa-t.html |title=N.W.A. World Tag Team Title (Chicago & Indianapolis) |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |author2= |date= |year=2003 |month= |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote= }}</ref> **NWA World Tag Team Championship (Los Angeles version) (1 time) - with Sandor Szabo <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ca/la/la-world-t.html |title=World Tag Team Title (Los Angeles) |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |author2= |date= |year=2003 |month= |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote= }}</ref> *'''Midwest Wrestling Association''' **Ohio Heavyweight Championship (2 times) <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/oh/oh-h.html |title=Ohio Heavyweight Title |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |author2= |date= |year=2003 |month= |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote= }}</ref> **Ohio Tag Team Championship (1 time) - with Rocco Columbo <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/oh/mwa/oh-t.html |title=Ohio Tag Team Title |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |author2= |date= |year=2003 |month= |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote= }}</ref> *'''[[Worldwide Wrestling Associates]]''' **[[WWA International Television Tag Team Championship]] ([[WWA International Television Tag Team Championship|1 time]]) - with [[Sandor Szabo (wrestler)|Sandor Szabo]] <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ca/la/nwa/int-tv-t.html |title=International Television Tag Team Title (Los Angeles) |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |author2= |date= |year=2003 |month= |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote= }}</ref> *'''[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]]''' **2007 Senator Hugh Farley Award recipient *'''Other Titles''' **World Heavyweight Championship ''(Jack Pfeffer version)'' <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/pfeffer-h.html |title=World Heavyweight title (by Jack Pfeffer) |accessdate= |author= |authorlink= |author2= |date= |year=2003 |month= |work= |publisher=Puroresu Dojo |pages= |language= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote= }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2007/09/08/4480688.html Profile] at SLAM! Sports * [http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/b/billy-darnell.html Profile at Online World Of Wrestling]

revision.text:
{{Infobox court case | name = The Case of Swans | court = [[Exchequer of Pleas]] | image = File:Coat of Arms of England (1558-1603).svg | date decided = Trinity Term, 1592 | full name = | citations = [1572] EngR 403
7 Co Rep 15
77 ER 435 | judges = | prior actions = | subsequent actions = | opinions = | transcripts = | keywords =prescription }} '''The Case of Swans''' (1592) Trinity Term, 34 [[Elizabeth I]], is a landmark decision in [[English law]]. ==Background== [[Dame (title)|Dame]] [[Giles Strangways (died 1562)#Family|Joan Young]] and Thomas Saunger received a [[writ]] from the [[Exchequer]], directing the [[High Sheriff of Dorset|Sheriff of Dorset]] to round up 400 loose [[swan]]s from the rivers of the county. Swans were Royal fowl, however, and a wild swan was considered the property of the monarch.Sir [[Edward Coke]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=SzlFAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA83&lpg=PA83&dq=Joan+Young+and+Thomas+Saunger&source=bl&ots=wKM9fjL1hn&sig=OBuFZV8B7pPmZepUyMh6I1mecRA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jEfJULHzCaWhiAek14DQDQ&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Joan%20Young%20and%20Thomas%20Saunger&f=false The reports of Sir Edward Coke in thirteen parts].J. Butterworth and Son, 1826 page 83Joseph Chitty, [https://books.google.com/books?id=mY89AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA833&lpg=PA833&dq=Joan+Young+and+Thomas+Saunger&source=bl&ots=MPYCYhElX2&sig=Bzztgg7dA2cD9oqXLNZ5hgBKxhk&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jEfJULHzCaWhiAek14DQDQ&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAw A treatise on the game laws and on fisheries]. W Clarke 1812 page 834 The right to these swans in [[Dorset]] had since [[time immemorial]] been held by the local abbot, who lost the right along with the [[Abbotsbury Abbey|abbey]] to [[Henry VIII]] at the [[dissolution of the Monasteries]]. Henry then granted the estate to [[Giles Strangways (died 1546)|Giles Strangways]], Dame Joan's deceased first husband, whose heir gave them a right to the swans for one year. The new Queen, Elizabeth I, now sought possession of the swans. ==Finding== The question was whether the swans were Strangways‚Äôs to grant or remained the Queen‚Äôs. Sir [[Edward Coke]], as [[Solicitor General for England and Wales|Solicitor General]], represented the Queen. The Court held that the swans that are ''[[ferae naturae]]'', or wild animals, cannot be given by transfer or taken by prescription. [http://oll.libertyfund.org/titles/911#lf0462-01_head_085 Sir Edward Coke, ''The Selected Writings and Speeches of Sir Edward Coke'', ed. Steve Sheppard] (Indianapolis: Liberty Fund, 2003). Vol. 1. 3/31/2017. == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:English property case law]] [[Category:1592 in law]] [[Category:1592 in England]] [[Category:1592 in English law]] [[Category:Edward Coke cases]] [[Category:Case law stubs]]

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=August 2008}} [[Image:Fa√ßade c√¥t√© jardin du ch√¢teau de Compi√®gne.jpg|thumb|250px|The Ch√¢teau de Compi√®gne seen from the garden]] [[Image:Compi√®gne Ch√¢teau 01.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Main staircase at the Ch√¢teau de Compi√®gne]] [[File:Picardie Compi√®gne3 tango7174.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Music lounge]]
The '''Ch√¢teau de Compi√®gne''' is a [[France|French]] [[chateau]], a royal residence built for [[Louis XV of France|Louis XV]] and restored by [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon]]. Compi√®gne was one of three seats of royal government, the others being [[Palace of Versailles|Versailles]] and [[Ch√¢teau de Fontainebleau|Fontainebleau]]. It is located in [[Compi√®gne]] in the [[Oise]] [[Departments of France|department]] and is open to the public.
Even before the chateau was constructed, Compi√®gne was the preferred summer residence for French monarchs, primarily for hunting given its proximity to Compi√®gne Forest. The first royal residence was built in 1374 for [[Charles V of France|Charles V]], and a long procession of successors both visited it and modified it. [[Louis XIV of France|Louis XIV]] resided in Compi√®gne some 75 times. Louis XV was perhaps even more favorably impressed; the [[Comte de Chevergny]] described his infatuation: "Hunting was his main passion... and Compi√®gne, with its immense forest, with its endless avenues amongst the trees, with its stretches down which you could ride all day and never come to the end, was the ideal place to indulge that passion."
In 1750, prominent architect [[Ange-Jacques Gabriel]] proposed a thorough renovation of the chateau. Work began in 1751 and was finished in 1788 by Gabriel's student [[Le Dreux de La Ch√¢tre]]. The ancient town ramparts dictated the ch√¢teau's triangular plan; the resultant building covers about {{convert|5|acre|m2}}. It is Neoclassical in style, with simplicity and clarity governing both its external and interior features.
During the [[French Revolution]], the ch√¢teau passed into the jurisdiction of the Minister for the Interior. In 1795 all furniture was sold and its works of art were sent to the [[Mus√©um Central]]; it was essentially gutted. Napoleon visited in 1799 and again in 1803. In 1804 the ch√¢teau became an imperial domain and in 1807 he ordered it be made habitable again. Architects Berthault, [[Charles Percier|Percier]] and [[Pierre Fran√ßois L√©onard Fontaine|Fontaine]], decorators Dubois and [[Pierre-Joseph Redout√©|Redout√©]], and cabinetmakers [[Fran√ßois-Honor√©-Georges Jacob-Desmalter|Jacob-Desmalter]] and Marcion restored the ch√¢teau. Its layout was altered, a ballroom added, and the garden was replanted and linked directly to the forest.
The result is an example of [[First French Empire]] style (1808-1810), though some traces of the earlier d√©cor survive. The writer [[Auguste Luchet]] remarked that "Compi√®gne speaks of Napoleon as Versailles does of Louis XIV". From 1856 on, [[Napoleon III of France|Napoleon III]] and Eug√©nie made it their autumn residence, and redecorated some rooms in the Second Empire style.
Today's visitors can find three distinct museums within the chateau: the apartments themselves; the Museum of the Second Empire; and the National Car Museum (Le Mus√©e de la Voiture), founded in 1927, with a collection of [[carriage]]s, [[bicycle]]s, and [[automobile]]s.
==External links== {{commons category|Ch√¢teau de Compi√®gne}} * [http://www.musee-chateau-compiegne.fr/ Ch√¢teau de Compi√®gne] - official site {{fr icon}} * [https://archive.is/20130107014824/http://www.musee-chateau-compiegne.fr/homes/home_id24350_u1l2.htm Panoramic views of the Ch√¢teau de Compi√®gne]
{{coord|49|25|09|N|2|49|52|E|display=title|region:FR_type:landmark_source:frwiki}} {{Royal Residences in France}}

system)|George 2]] |- |{{rh}} | Version 6 Unix file system (V6FS) | [[Bell Labs]] | 1972 | [[Version 6 Unix]] |- |{{rh}} | [[RT-11]] file system | [[Digital Equipment Corporation|DEC]] | 1973 | [[RT-11]] |- |{{rh}} | Disk Operating System ([[GEC DOS]]) | [[The General Electric Company plc|GEC]] | 1973 | Core Operating System |- |{{rh}} | [[CP/M file system]] | [[Digital Research]] ([[Gary Kildall]]) | 1974 | [[CP/M]]{{cite web |url=http://www.computerhistory.org/atchm/in-his-own-words-gary-kildall/ |title=In His Own Words: Gary Kildall |author-first=Len |author-last=Shustek |date=2016-08-02 |work=Remarkable People |publisher=[[Computer History Museum]]}}{{cite paper|orig-year=1993|date=2016-08-02|title=Computer Connections: People, Places, and Events in the Evolution of the Personal Computer Industry|author-first=Gary Arlen|author-last=Kildall|author-link=Gary Kildall|editor-first1=Scott|editor-last1=Kildall|editor-link=Scott File system ! Maximum [[filename]] length ! Allowable characters in directory entries{{efn |name=note-25 |These are the restrictions imposed by the on-disk directory entry structures themselves. Particular [[Installable File System]] drivers may place restrictions of their own on file and directory names; [[operating system]]s may also place restrictions of their own, across all filesystems. [[DOS]], [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], and [[OS/2]] allow only the following characters from the current 8-bit [[OEM codepage]] in SFNs: A-Z, 0-9, characters ! # $ % & ' ( ) - @ ^ _ ` { } ~, as well as 0x80-0xFF and 0x20 (SPACE). Specifically, lowercase letters a-z, characters " * / : < > ? \ | + , . ; = [ ], control codes 0x00-0x1F, 0x7F and in some cases also 0xE5 are not allowed.) In LFNs, any [[UCS-2]] [[Unicode]] except \ / : ? * " > < | and NUL are allowed in file and directory names across all filesystems. [[Unix-like]] systems disallow the characters / and NUL in file and directory names across all filesystems.}} ! Maximum pathname length ! Maximum file size ! Maximum volume size{{efn |name=note-4 |For filesystems that have variable allocation unit (block/cluster) sizes, a range of size are given, indicating the maximum volume sizes for the minimum and the maximum possible allocation unit sizes of the filesystem (e.g. 512 bytes and 128 [[kibibyte|KiB]] for FAT ‚Äî which is the cluster size range allowed by the on-disk data structures, although some [[Installable File System]] drivers and [[operating system]]s do not support cluster sizes larger than 32 [[kibibyte|KiB]]).}} !Max number of files |- | {{rh}} |[[BeeGFS]] |255 bytes |Any byte except NUL{{efn |name=note-26}} |No limit defined{{efn |name=note-12}} |16 [[exbibyte|EiB]] |16 [[exbibyte|EiB]] | {{dunno}} |- | {{rh}} | [[CP/M file system]] | 8.3 | [[ASCII]] except for < > . , ; : = ? * [ ] | No directory hierarchy (but accessibility of files depends on user areas via USER command since [[CP/M 2.2]]) | data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="0" | 32 MiB | data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="0" | 512 MiB | {{dunno}} |- | {{rh}} | IBM SFS | 8.8 | {{dunno}} | {{dunno}} | data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="0" | Non-hierarchical{{cite web |title=SFS file system |website=IBM Knowledge Center |url=http://www-01.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SS6SGM_3.1.0/com.ibm.aix.cbl.doc/PGandLR/ref/rpfio50.htm}} | data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="0" {{dunno}} | {{dunno}} |- | {{rh}} | [[DECtape]] | 6.3 | A‚ÄìZ, 0‚Äì9 | DTxN:FILNAM.EXT = 15 | data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="369280" | 369,280 bytes (577 * 640) | data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="369280" | 369,920 bytes (578 * 640) | {{dunno}} |- | {{rh}} | [[Elektronika BK]] tape format | 16 bytes | {{dunno}} | No directory hierarchy | data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="65536" | 64 KiB | data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="800000" | Not limited. Directory entries with these names are not prohibited, and indeed exist as normal directory entries in the on-disk data structures. However, they are mandatory directory entries, with mandatory values, that are automatically created in each directory when it is created; and directories without them are considered corrupt.}} | No limit defined{{efn |name=note-12 |The on-disk structures have no inherent limit. Particular [[Installable File System]] drivers and [[operating system]]s may impose limits of their own, however. Limited by its Current Directory Structure (CDS), [[DOS]] does not support more than 32 directory levels (except for [[DR DOS 3.31]]-[[DR DOS 6.0|6.0]]) or full pathnames longer than 66 bytes for FAT, or 255 characters for LFNs. Windows NT does not support full pathnames longer than 32,767 bytes for NTFS. Linux has a pathname limit of 4,096.}} | data-sort-type="number" data-sort-value="16777216" | 16 [[mebibyte|MiB]]{{efn |name=note-57 |The file size in the inode is 1 8-bit byte followed by 1 16-bit word, for 24 bits. [[NTFS]] | {{yes}} | {{yes}}{{efn |As of Windows Vista, NTFS fully supports symbolic links.{{cite magazine|url=https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/7f4942ce-a782-49a7-bfbb-220337a0cd92|title=Windows Administration: Inside the Windows Vista Kernel: Part 1|author=Mark Russinovich|authorlink=Mark Russinovich|date=February 2007|magazine=[[Microsoft TechNet|TechNet]]}} NTFS 3.0 (Windows 2000) and higher can create ''junctions'', which allow entire directories (but not individual files) to be mapped to elsewhere in the directory tree of the same partition (file system). These are implemented through ''reparse points'', which allow the normal process of filename resolution to be extended in a flexible manner.}} | {{no}}{{efn |name=note-37 |NTFS stores everything, even the file data, as meta-data, so its log is closer to block journaling.}} | {{yes}}{{efn |name=note-37}} (2000) | {{yes}}{{efn |name=note-36 |While NTFS itself supports case sensitivity, the Win32 environment subsystem cannot create files whose names differ only by case for compatibility reasons. When a file is opened for writing, if there is any existing file whose name is a case-insensitive match for the new file, the existing file is truncated and opened for writing instead of a new file with a different name being created. Other subsystems like e. g. [[Services for Unix]], that operate directly above the kernel and not on top of Win32 can have case-sensitivity.}} | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | {{partial}}{{efn |name=note-93 |NTFS does not internally support snapshots, but in conjunction with the [[Volume Shadow Copy Service]] can maintain persistent block differential volume snapshots.}} | {{dunno}} | {{yes}} | {{yes}}{{efn |name=note-NTFS-Dedup |Supported only on Windows Server SKUs. However, partitions deduplicated on Server can be used on Client.}}{{cite web|url=https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh769303(v=vs.85).aspx|title=About Data Deduplication}} | {{no}} |- ! [[HFS Plus]] | {{yes}}{{cite web|last1=Siracusa|first1=John|title=Mac OS X 10.7 Lion: the Ars Technica review|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2011/07/mac-os-x-10-7/12/#hfs-problems|website=Ars Technica|accessdate=14 December 2017|quote=To keep track of hard links, HFS+ creates a separate file for each hard link inside a hidden directory at the root level of the volume.}} | {{yes}} | {{no}} | {{yes}}{{efn |name=note-48 |Metadata-only journaling was introduced in the Mac OS X 10.2.2 HFS Plus driver; journaling is enabled by default on Mac OS X 10.3 and later.}} | {{partial}}{{efn |Although often believed to be case sensitive, HFS Plus normally is not. The typical default installation is case-preserving only. From Mac OS X 10.3 on the command ''newfs_hfs -s'' will create a case-sensitive new file system.{{man|8|newfs_hfs|Darwin}} HFS Plus version 5 optionally supports case-sensitivity. However, since case-sensitivity is fundamentally different from case-insensitivity, a new signature was required so existing HFS Plus utilities would not see case-sensitivity as a file system error that needed to be corrected. Since the new signature is 'HX', it is often believed this is a new filesystem instead of a simply an upgraded version of HFS Plus.{{cite web |publisher=Apple |url=https://developer.apple.com/documentation/MacOSX/Conceptual/BPFileSystem/Articles/Comparisons.html |title=File System Comparisons}} (hasn't been updated to discuss HFSX){{cite web |publisher=Apple |url=https://developer.apple.com/technotes/tn/tn1150.html |title=Technical Note TN1150: HFS Plus Volume Format}} (Very technical overview of HFS Plus and HFSX.)}} | {{yes}} | {{yes}}{{efn |Mac OS X Tiger (10.4) and late versions of Panther (10.3) provide file change logging (it's a feature of the file system software, not of the volume format, actually).[http://www.kernelthread.com/software/fslogger/ fslogger]}} | {{no}} | {{no}} | {{no}}{{efn |name=note-77 |HFS+ does not actually encrypt files: to implement [[FileVault]], OS X creates an HFS+ filesystem in a sparse, encrypted disk image that is automatically mounted over the home directory when the user logs in.}} | {{no}} | {{no}} |- ! Added tags to the page using [[Wikipedia:Page Curation|Page Curation]] (refimprove)
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2018}}
{{italic title}} '''''Constructing a Story''''' (French: ''Construire un r√©cit'') by filmmaker and script doctor [[Yves Lavandier]] (''[[Writing Drama]]''), is a treatise on conceiving and writing stories for the cinema, the theater, television, and comic books, but also for novels, albeit to a lesser degree. The English edition, translated by story consultant Alexis Niki, was published in May 2017 by Le Clown & l‚ÄôEnfant.
==Content== Upon the re-publication of the French version of ''[[Writing Drama]]'' in 2011, [[Yves Lavandier]] decided to extract the book‚Äôs most useful chapters and to create two stand-alone books: ''Construire un r√©cit'' and ''Evaluer un sc√©nario'' (''[[Analyzing a Script]]''). ''Construire un r√©cit'' grew from 50 pages in the French version of ''Writing Drama'' to 170, and then to 220 for the 2016 edition.
''Constructing a Story'' is a practical handbook on how to write a narrative. Yves Lavandier‚Äôs ambition is to help authors who want to tell a story convey their thoughts and their universe in an accessible way. For this he proposes a method that starts from the meaning the author wants to communicate to arrive at the complete narrative via the steps of the pitch, the foundations, the milestones, the step outline, and the treatment. The general principle of Lavandier‚Äôs approach is: "''You don‚Äôt build a house starting with the wallpaper.''"
As in ''[[Writing Drama]]'', the author puts forth a vision of the ''[[three-act structure]]'' that differs to that of many Anglo-Saxon theorists and that he considers "''simple, logical, and more importantly, natural: before the action, during the action, after the action."''
In addition to several passages covering the work of characterization, a large chapter is dedicated entirely to the character arc, the potential for psychological transformation for one of the characters. The author proposes tools to justify such a transformation and analyzes some twenty works from the specific angle of the character arc. Among these are: ''[[The Apartment]]'', ''[[Casablanca (film)|Casablanca]]'', ''[[A Christmas Carol]]'', ''[[Groundhog Day]]'', ''[[The Lives of Others]]'', ''[[Oedipus Rex]]'', ''[[One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (film)|One Flew Over the Cuckoo‚Äôs Nest]]'', ''[[One Thousand and One Nights]]'', ''[[Schindler‚Äôs List]]'', ''[[The Taming of the Shrew]]'', and ''[[Toy Story]]''. In his analysis of the beginning of ''[[Tootsie]]'', for example, [[Yves Lavandier]] points out that contrary to many other analyses, the protagonist (Dustin Hoffman) is not actually characterized as a chauvinist who needs to learn to respect women.
== Front cover==
The cover photo represents romanesco broccoli, a natural example of fractal structure. [[Yves Lavandier]] considers the objective-obstacle pairing to be the basic pattern of story, and to follow the fractal principle. In Lavandier‚Äôs view, narrative is the combination, at different scales, of thousands of objective-obstacle pairings and of their resulting mechanisms: the protagonist, the inciting incident, the three-act structure, the climax, etc. The author uses ''[[Once Upon a Time in the West]]'' to illustrate his point.
==Reception==
In the magazine L‚ÄôAvant-Sc√®ne Cin√©ma issue 609 (January 2014), Jean-Philippe Gu√©rand writes : "''Constructing a Story is a veritable guide of writing know-how in which the author prods his reader and pushes the emerging screenwriter to give his best with sections such as "Be ferocious to your protagonist" or "Make the audience participate," and is applicable to both cinema and television.<ref>[http://www.avantscenecinema.com/numero-609-seul-contre-tous-de-gaspar-noe/ L‚ÄôAvant-Sc√®ne Cin√©ma {{n¬∞|609}} (janvier 2014)]</ref>"
Screenwriter and game designer Antoine Bauza states: "''While it can‚Äôt replace the reading of the sacrosanct tome ''[[Writing Drama]]'', Constructing a Story is a gold mine in its own right (and an excellent complement) for writers. It gave me precious advice as well as a solid dose of motivation.<ref>[http://www.clown-enfant.com/leclown/ConstruireUnRecit-temoignages.htm Comment by Antoine Bauza]</ref>''"
For film agent Julian Friedmann, ''Constructing a Story'' manages to get underneath the skin of the story.<ref>[https://twitter.com/julianfriedmann/status/878927567620853761 Tweet by Julian Friedmann]</ref>
"''The chapter on creating story and character arcs is unique''", writes screenwriter and novelist Ann Kimbrough, "''I‚Äôve never seen anyone break down arcs in this manner. I found it very useful as a writer of any medium. It‚Äôs a MUST READ part of the book.<ref>[https://screenwritersdailydose.com/2017/08/04/constructing-a-story-book-review/ Review by Ann Kimbrough]</ref>''"
For screenwriter, teacher and script consultant Elana Golden, "''Constructing a Story is also a meditation on the creative process in general and cinema in particular, with examples from European and American films and from psychology, philosophy, classic theater and archetypal stories.<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Constructing-Story-Yves-Lavandier/dp/2910606147/#customerReviews Review by Elana Golden]</ref>''"
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.clown-enfant.com/leclown/ConstructingAStory/ The publisher's website devoted to ''Constructing a Story''] * [http://www.clown-enfant.com/leclown/ConstructingAStory/excerpts.htm Excerpts from the book]

revision.text:
'''Edwin A. (Eddie) Goodman''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|PC|OC|QC}} (1918 ‚Äì August 23, 2006) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] lawyer and political figure.
Goodman graduated from Toronto's [[Osgoode Hall Law School]] in 1947<ref>https://issuu.com/osgoodealumni/docs/2007_continuum__revised__4_23__2010_/18</ref> and was one of the founding partners of [[Goodmans|Goodmans LLP]], a [[Toronto]] law firm as well as a life bencher of the [[Law Society of Upper Canada]]. He is best known, however, for his political work as an advisor and fundraiser for both the [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada]] and particularly the [[Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario]], having been a friend and advisor to both [[Premier of Ontario|Premier]] [[John Robarts]] and Premier [[Bill Davis]]. He has served as the national chair of the Progressive Conservative Party of Canada and as vice-president of both the Ontario and federal Progressive Conservative Party.
Goodman was also active in charity work as honorary president of [[Scouts Canada]] and as a director for various bodies such as the Baycrest Centre for Geriatric Care and [[Princess Margaret Cancer Centre|Princess Margaret Hospital]]. He was also chairman of the [[Royal Ontario Museum]] for six years.
He was considered a [[Red Tory]] and was part of the circle known as the [[Big Blue Machine]] that helped keep the Ontario Tories in power under Robarts and Davis.
He once ran for public office losing to Communist [[J.B. Salsberg]] of the [[Labor-Progressive Party]] after World War II.
In April 1975 his daughter Joanne Goodman was killed in a highway accident. He named a lecture series at the [[University of Western Ontario]] which every year invites a history to give a series of lectures to the University community <ref>{{cite web |url=http://history.uwo.ca/events/joannegoodmanlectures.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100913034858/http://history.uwo.ca/events/joannegoodmanlectures.html |archivedate=2010-09-13 |df= }}</ref>
In 1992, Goodman was named to the [[Security Intelligence Review Committee]] and was appointed to the [[Queen's Privy Council for Canada]].
His autobiography, ''The Life of the Party'', was published in 1988. He is also an Officer of the [[Order of Canada]].
Goodman died following a heart attack.
==References== {{reflist}} *Rob Feguson, [https://www.thestar.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?pagename=thestar/Layout/Article_Type1&call_pageid=971358637177&c=Article&cid=1156369812517 `Patriot and philanthropist' Toronto lawyer was Tory stalwart Received Order of Canada in 1983], ''Toronto Star'', August 24, 2006
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070930050445/http://www.gg.ca/honours/search-recherche/honours-desc.asp?lang=e&TypeID=orc&id=657 Order of Canada Citation]
{{Authority control}}

{{about|the 1988 film|the character|Cassandra Peterson|the video game|Elvira: Mistress of the Dark (video game)}} {{Infobox film | name = Elvira, Mistress of the Dark | image = elviramistressofthedarkposter.jpg | alt = A woman dressed in black is tied up and about to be burned at the stake | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[James Signorelli]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Eric Gardner * Mark Pierson }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * [[Sam Egan]] * [[John Paragon]] * [[Cassandra Peterson]] }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Cassandra Peterson|Elvira]] * [[W. Morgan Sheppard]] * [[Daniel Greene (actor)|Daniel Greene]] * [[Jeff Conaway]] * [[Susan Kellermann]] * [[Edie McClurg]] }} | music = James B. Campbell | cinematography = Hanania Bier | editing = Battle Davis | studio = {{Plainlist| * [[New World Pictures]] * [[NBC Productions]] }} | distributor = New World Pictures | released = {{Film date|1988|9|30}} | runtime = 96 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $7.5 million | gross = $5.5 million<ref>{{mojo title|elviramistressofthedark|Elvira, Mistress of the Dark}}</ref> }} '''''Elvira, Mistress of the Dark''''' is a 1988 American [[comedy horror]] film directed by [[James Signorelli]]. [[Cassandra Peterson]] plays the role of [[horror host]]ess Elvira in the character's feature film debut. The screenplay was written by Peterson, [[John Paragon]] and [[Sam Egan]].<ref>{{cite news|title= 'Elvira' Matches Films She Introduces on TV |publisher= LA Times|date=1988-09-30|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1988-09-30/entertainment/ca-3005_1_midnight-movie|accessdate=2010-08-24 | first=Kevin | last=Thomas}}</ref>
==Plot== [[Los Angeles]] TV horror hostess Elvira, Mistress of the Dark quits her job after the station's new owner [[sexual harassment|sexually harasses]] her. She plans to open an act in [[Las Vegas]], but needs $50,000 for the project. Upon learning she is a [[beneficiary]] of her deceased great-aunt Morgana, she travels to Fallwell, [[Massachusetts]], to claim the inheritance, which includes a mansion, a recipe book and Morgana's pet [[poodle]], Algonquin.
In Fallwell, Elvira's worldly attitude and revealing clothes set the conservative town council against her. But theater operator Bob Redding befriends her. The town's teenagers quickly accept her, to the chagrin of their parents, who consider her a bad influence. Bowling alley owner Patty is interested in Bob, and at her late-night gory [[film festival]] she was presenting at Bob's theater she succeeds in humiliating Elvira. Elvira struggles to sell the house, so she can depart for Las Vegas. Meanwhile, she is unaware that her harsh but seemingly-harmless uncle Vincent is actually a [[warlock]] who is obsessed with obtaining Morgana's [[grimoire|spellbook]]; he plans to kill Elvira and conquer the world, and has been fuelling the townspeople's hostility.
Elvira tries to impress Bob with a home-cooked dinner, but mistakenly uses the spellbook as a [[cookbook]] and summons a creature that attacks them. Elvira learns that the book was her mother Divana's spellbook, and that Morgana hid her to protect her from Vincent. When Elvira tries to unleash the creature against the Morality Club at their picnic, she prepares the brew incorrectly and it instead has an [[aphrodisiac]] effect; the adults remove each other's clothing indiscriminately and are arrested for [[indecent exposure]]. When Patty confronts Elvira, the resulting fistfight ends up humiliating Patty by revealing that her bra is stuffed.
Vincent leads the townspeople in arresting Elvira for [[witchcraft]], which is still illegal in the state. They decide to [[death by burning|burn her at the stake]]. The teenagers try to free her from jail, but fail and accidentally lock themselves into a different cell. Bob tries to recover the spellbook from the mansion, but is tied up by Vincent, who takes the book. Algonquin transforms into a rat and unties Bob. Elvira is tied to a stake and the fire is lit, but she uses Morgana's ring to summon rain that quenches the fire; she escapes with Bob. At the mansion, Elvira and Vincent engage in a magical battle that sets fire to the house. Elvira banishes Vincent to the [[underworld]], while the house and all of the magical artifacts are destroyed.
The next day, Elvira prepares to leave town. The townspeople apologize for their behavior, and everyone asks Elvira to stay. She kisses Bob but, as she is homeless, she insists that she must leave. Elvira has inherited Vincent's estate, which included enough money to open her show in Las Vegas. At a Las Vegas hotel, Elvira performs a lavishly produced musical number.
==Cast== * [[Cassandra Peterson]] as Elvira / Aunt Morgana Talbot * [[W. Morgan Sheppard]] as Great-Uncle Vincent Talbot * [[Daniel Greene (actor)|Daniel Greene]] as Bob Redding * [[Susan Kellermann]] as Patty * [[Edie McClurg]] as Chastity Pariah * Robert Benedetti as Mr. Calvin Cobb * [[Kurt Fuller]] as Mr. Glotter * [[Jeff Conaway]] as Travis * [[William Duell]] as Lesley Meeker * [[Pat Crawford Brown]] as Mrs. Meeker * Ellen Dunning as Robin Meeker * [[Ira Heiden]] as Bo * [[Tress MacNeille]] as anchor woman / voice of Aunt Morgana Talbot * [[Frank Welker]] as voice of Algonquin
==Soundtrack== The original [[Film score|music score]] was composed by James B. Campbell and the soundtrack features the single "I Put a Spell on You" performed by [[Joanna St. Claire]].
==Reception== Review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film an approval rating of 47% based on reviews from 15 critics, indicating mixed reviews.<ref>https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/elvira_mistress_of_the_dark/</ref>
===Awards and nominations=== {{Anchor|Awards|Accolades}} The film received a [[Razzie Award]] nomination for Cassandra Peterson as [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Actress|Worst Actress]] in 1989, losing to [[Liza Minnelli]] for both ''[[Arthur 2: On the Rocks]]'' and ''[[Rent-a-Cop (film)|Rent-a-Cop]]''.
===Nominations=== [[Fantasporto]] * ''Best film'': 1990<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000236/1990 IMDb Fantasporto 1990]</ref>
[[Saturn Awards]] * ''Best Actress'': [[Cassandra Peterson]] ‚Äì 1990<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000004/1990 IMDb Saturn Awards 1990]</ref>
[[Golden Raspberry]] * ''Worst Actress'': [[Cassandra Peterson]] ‚Äì 1988<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.razzies.com/forum/1988-razzie-nominees-winners_topic338.html |title=Razzie 1988 |publisher=Razzies.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-02}}</ref>
[[Stinkers Bad Movie Awards]] * ''Worst Picture'': 1988<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://theenvelope.latimes.com/extras/lostmind/year/1988/1988st.htm |title=1988 11th Hastings Bad Cinema Society Stinkers Awards |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2013 |work=[[Stinkers Bad Movie Awards]] |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061017164853/http://theenvelope.latimes.com/extras/lostmind/year/1988/1988st.htm |archivedate=October 17, 2006 }}</ref>
==Other work== In 2001, The Elvira Movie Company and Media Pro Pictures released ''[[Elvira's Haunted Hills]]'', the second film with Peterson in the title role.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.myspace.com/2macabre |title=Official MySpace |publisher=Myspace.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-07}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Wikiquote|Elvira, Mistress of the Dark}} * {{IMDb title|0095088}} * {{Amg title|15650}} * {{mojo title|elviramistressofthedark}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|elvira_mistress_of_the_dark}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''Flaming Teeth''', from [[Fiji]]an [[mythology]], was a [[Giant (mythology)|giant]] who was so large his [[tooth|teeth]] appeared as burning logs.
The giant tormented villages day after day, eating people and wreaking havoc. After so much burning and consuming of villagers a band of brave men from the village got together. They made a plan to surprise and ambush the giant by luring it under a giant rock and smashing its skull with it. They succeeded killing the giant but its teeth still were aflame. The villagers took the teeth back to the village and that was the first time man acquired the use of fire.<ref>Gilmore, David D.: ''Monsters: Evil Beings, Mythical Beasts, and All Manner of Imaginary Terrors'', page 123. University of Pennsylvania Press, 2003.</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://macula.tv/gallery/Illustration/gallery/flamingteeth/gallery.htm Macula.tv's cartoon illustration of Flaming Teeth]

revision.text:
The '''HABU equivalent''' is a [[Units of measurement|unit of measurement]] used by [[United States Department of Defense]]'s [[High Performance Computing Modernization Program]] to evaluate the performance of [[supercomputer|large computers systems]].
"The [HPCMP method for measuring system performance] is as follows: the ratio of time [for a given benchmark application] at a target processor count provides a relative measure of the system's performance on that application test case compared with the DoD standard system, stated in Habu-equivalents. Habu, the first DoD standard system, is an IBM [[POWER3]] formerly located at the US [[Naval Oceanographic Office]] (NAVO) [[Major Shared Resource Center]]. One Habu-equivalent is the performance of 1,024 system-under-study processors compared with 1,024 Habu processors.<ref>Larry P. Davis, Cray J. Henry, Roy L. Campbell Jr, William A. Ward. High Performance Computing Acquisitions Based on the Factors that Matter. Computing in Science & Engineering. IEEE Computer Society / American Institute of Physics. November/December 2007</ref>
==References== <references />

{{Other ships|HMAS Vampire}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2011}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=Australian national maritime museum ships cr.jpg |Ship caption=HMAS ''Vampire'', {{HMAS|Onslow}}, and the [[HM Bark Endeavour Replica|HM Bark ''Endeavour'' replica]] on display at the Australian National Maritime Museum }} {{Infobox ship career |Ship country=Australia |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|Australia|naval}} |Ship builder=[[Cockatoo Island Dockyard]] |Ship laid down=1 July 1953 |Ship launched=27 October 1956 |Ship commissioned=23 June 1959 |Ship decommissioned=13 August 1986 |Ship reclassified=Training ship (1980) |Ship motto=*"''Audamus''" *Latin: "Let Us Be Daring"{{efn|''Audamus'' is meaningless in Latin. Cassells, who discovered the error during a review of RAN badges in September 1974, believes that the motto should have been ''Aud'''e'''amus'' as it matches the provided English translation of "Let Us Be Daring" or "Let Us Dare".<ref>Cassells, ''The Destroyers'', p. 150</ref>}} |Ship nickname=*"The [[Bat Mobile]]" *"The Bat" *"The Mean Machine"<ref name=Shaw25/> |Ship honours=*[[Indonesia‚ÄìMalaysia confrontation|Malaysia]] 1964‚Äì66 *Plus six [[HMAS Vampire#Battle honours|inherited battle honours]] |Ship status=Preserved as museum ship |Ship notes= |Ship badge= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Ship class=''Daring'' class destroyer |Ship displacement=*2,800 tons standard *3,560 tons full load |Ship length={{convert|388|ft|11.5|in|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|42|ft|11.375|in|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|12|ft|9|in|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=2 √ó Foster Wheeler boilers, English Electric geared turbines, 2 shafts, {{convert|54,000|SHP|abbr=on}} |Ship speed=Over {{convert|30|kn}} |Ship range={{convert|3700|nmi|lk=in}} at {{convert|20|kn}} |Ship complement=20 officers, 300 sailors |Ship sensors=*'''Sonar:''' *Type 170 attack *Type 174 search *Type 185 submarine detection *'''Radar:''' *Flyplane 3 gunfire director (remove 1970‚Äì71) *MRS 8 gunfire director (remove 1970‚Äì71) *2 √ó M22 gunfire directors (installed 1970‚Äì71) *LW-02 air search (installed 1970‚Äì71) *8gr-301A surface search and navigation |Ship armament=*6 √ó [[QF 4.5 inch Mk I ‚Äì V naval gun|QF 4.5-inch (113-mm) guns]] (3 dual turrets) *6 √ó [[Bofors 40 mm|{{convert|40|mm|in|adj=on}} Bofors]] anti-aircraft guns (2 twin mountings, 2 single mountings) *4 √ó [[M2 Browning machine gun|{{convert|0.5|in|mm|adj=on}} Browning machine guns]] *1 √ó 5-tube {{convert|21|in|mm|adj=on}} Mark IV torpedo launcher *1 √ó [[Limbo (weapon)|Limbo anti-submarine mortar]] (later removed) *[[Sea Cat missile]] system (installed later) |Ship notes= }} |} '''HMAS ''Vampire''''' was the third of three Australian-built [[Daring class destroyer (1949)|''Daring'' class]] destroyers serving in the [[Royal Australian Navy]] (RAN). One of the first all-welded ships built in Australia, she was constructed at [[Cockatoo Island Dockyard]] between 1952 and 1959, and was commissioned into the RAN a day after completion.
''Vampire'' was regularly deployed to South East Asia during her career: she was attached to the [[Far East Strategic Reserve]] on five occasions, including during the [[Indonesia-Malaysia Confrontation]], and escorted the troop transport {{HMAS|Sydney|R17|6}} on six of the latter's twenty-five transport voyages to Vietnam. In 1977, the destroyer was assigned to escort the Royal Yacht [[HMY Britannia|''Britannia'']] during [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]] and [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Prince Phillip]]'s visit to Australia. In 1980, ''Vampire'' was reclassified as a training ship.
The warship remained in service until 1986, when she was decommissioned and presented to the [[Australian National Maritime Museum]] for preservation as a [[museum ship]]; the largest museum-owned object on display in Australia.
==Design== {{Main|Daring class destroyer (1949)}} The Royal Australian Navy initially ordered four [[Daring class destroyer (1949)|''Daring'' class destroyers]], which were to be named after the ships of the "[[Scrap Iron Flotilla]]" of World War II. The ships were modified during construction: most changes were made to improve habitability, including the installation of air-conditioning.<ref name=Coop167>Cooper, in Stevens, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', p. 167</ref> ''Vampire'' and her sister ships were the first all-welded ships to be constructed in Australia.<ref name=Coop168>Cooper, in Stevens, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', p. 168</ref>
The ''Daring''s had a standard [[displacement (ship)|displacement]] of 2,800 tons, which increased to 3,600 tons at full load.<ref name=Bastock320/> ''Vendetta'' and her sisters were {{convert|390|ft|m}} long, with a [[beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|43|ft|m}}, and a [[draught (hull)|draught]] of {{convert|12|ft|9|in|m}} at mean, and {{convert|14|ft|6|in|m}} at full or deep load.<ref name=Bastock320/> Her propulsion system consisted of two Foster Wheeler boilers, feeding two English Electric geared turbines, which provided {{convert|54000|hp}} to two propeller shafts.<ref name=Bastock320/> ''Vampire'' could sail at over {{convert|30|kn|lk=in}}, and had a range of {{convert|3700|nmi|lk=in}} at {{convert|20|kn}}.<ref name=Bastock320/> Her standard ship's company consisted of 20 officers and 300 sailors.<ref name=Bastock320/>
===Armament=== ''Vampire''{{'}}s main armament consisted of six [[QF 4.5 inch Mk I ‚Äì V naval gun|{{convert|4.5|in|mm|adj=on}} Mark V guns]] mounted in three Mark 6 twin turrets, two forward and one aft.<ref name=Bastock320/><ref name=Cassells147.8/><ref name=Shaw9>Shaw, ''HMAS Vampire'', p. 9</ref> Her anti-aircraft outfit consisted of six [[40 mm Bofors]]; two single mountings on the forward superstructure, and two twin mountings on the aft superstructure.<ref name=Bastock320>Bastock, ''Australia's Ships of War'', p. 320</ref> Four [[M2 Browning machine gun|{{convert|0.5|in|mm|adj=on}} Browning machine guns]] were carried for point defence.<ref name=Cassells147.8>Cassells, ''The Destroyers'', pp. 147‚Äì8</ref> Five 21-inch torpedo tubes were fitted to a single Mark IV pentad mount on the deck between the forward and aft superstructures.<ref name=Cassells147.8/> For anti-submarine warfare, a [[Limbo (weapon)|Limbo]] anti-submarine mortar was carried on the aft deck, offset to port.<ref name=Bastock320/> The twin Bofors, torpedo launcher, and Limbo mortar were all removed during various refits.<ref name=Cassells149/><ref name=Shaw10>Shaw, ''HMAS Vampire'', p. 10</ref> A [[Sea Cat missile]] system was installed at some point during her career.<ref name=Cassells147.8/>
[[File:HMAS Vampire forward.jpg|thumb|left|Forward section of ''Vampire''. The forward two 4.5-inch gun turrets are visible, and one of the single-mount Bofors is located near the left edge of the image.]] ''Vampire'' was fitted with a Type 170 attack sonar, a Type 174 search sonar, and a Type 185 submarine detection sonar.<ref name=Shaw25>Shaw, ''HMAS Vampire'', p. 25</ref> The original fire control directors were a Flyplane 3 and an MRS 8.<ref name=Shaw7>Shaw, ''HMAS Vampire'', p. 7</ref> These were replaced during the 1970‚Äì71 refit with two M22 units.<ref name=Shaw7/> The air warning radar{{clarify|date=November 2010}} was replaced with an LW-02 air search radar during the same refit, and an 8gr-301A surface search and navigation radar was installed.<ref name=Cassells149/><ref name=Shaw7/>
==Construction== ''Vampire'' was laid down at [[Cockatoo Island Dockyard]] in Sydney, New South Wales on 1 July 1952.<ref name=Cassells148>Cassells, ''The Destroyers'', p. 148</ref> The destroyer was launched on 27 October 1956 by the wife of the Governor-General, [[William Slim, 1st Viscount Slim|Sir William Slim]].<ref name=Bastock321>Bastock, ''Australia's Ships of War'', p. 321</ref> She was completed on 22 June 1959, and commissioned into the RAN in Sydney a day later.<ref name=Cassells148/> Between laying down and completion, the ship's cost increased from [[Australian pound|A¬£]]2.6 million to A¬£7 million.<ref name=Coop168/>
==Operational history== ===1959‚Äì1970=== After competing work-up trials and entering active service, ''Vampire'' underwent training exercises with ships of the RAN and [[Royal New Zealand Navy]] (RNZN) until early 1960.<ref name=Cassells148/> ''Vampire'' was deployed to the [[Far East Strategic Reserve]] in March 1960, and sailed to Singapore after a brief visit to New Zealand.<ref name=Cassells148/> She returned to Sydney in December, and was docked for refit until April 1961.<ref name=Cassells148/> The destroyer was awarded the [[Gloucester Cup]] for 1960, recognising her as the most efficient ship in the RAN.<ref name=Bastock321/> Following the refit, ''Vampire'' operated in Australian waters, including participation in the training exercise Tuckerbox in August, then returned to the Far East in September.<ref name=Bastock322>Bastock, ''Australia's Ships of War'', p. 322</ref> On 1 December 1961, a chief petty officer died aboard from illness.<ref>Cassells, ''The Destroyers'', p. 152</ref> The destroyer was in Hong Kong for Christmas, then in January 1962, visited [[Nha Trang]] and [[Saigon]] in Vietnam with {{HMAS|Quickmatch|G92|6}}.<ref>Cooper, in Stevens, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', p. 203</ref> ''Vampire'' received the Gloucester Cup again for 1961.<ref name=Bastock322/> the first months of 1962, the ship participated in training exercises in the South China Sea and the Bay of Bengal, before returning to Australia on 7 April.<ref name=Bastock322/> ''Vampire'' participated in Exercise Tuckerbox II during August and September, and was present at [[Fremantle, Western Australia]] during November for the [[1962 British Empire and Commonwealth Games|British Empire and Commonwealth Games in Perth]].<ref name=Bastock322/>
[[File:HMAS Vampire (D11) underway c1962.jpg|thumb|left|''Vampire'' in 1962]] On 31 January 1963, ''Vampire'' departed for her third FESR deployment, which lasted until late July.<ref name=Bastock322/> During this, the destroyer participated in [[South East Asia Treaty Organisation]] (SEATO) Exercise Sea Serpent.<ref name=Bastock322/> After returning to Sydney, ''Vampire'' was taken in hand by Garden Island Dockyard for refit, which concluded in February 1964.<ref name=Bastock322/> During the docking, the ship was awarded the Gloucester Cup for 1963; the third time the award was granted to the ship.<ref name=Bastock322/> After post-refit trials, ''Vampire'' sailed for her fourth Far East deployment in June, and was involved in Exercise Litgas shortly after reaching the region.<ref name=Bastock322/> From October until January 1965, the ship was involved in the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] response to the [[Indonesia-Malaysia Confrontation]]; carrying out patrols around the Malay Peninsula to interdict vessels smuggling troops into Malaysia.<ref name=Shaw6>Shaw, ''HMAS Vampire'', p. 6</ref> The destroyer remained in South East Asia until January 1965, and returned to Sydney on 12 February.<ref name=Bastock322/>
After a short period of leave and self-maintenance, ''Vampire'' sailed again for the Far East in April, exercising with the [[French frigate Doudart de Lagree (F728)|French frigate ''Doudart de Lagree'']] en route from Manus Island to Manila.<ref>{{cite news |title=Doudart Days With Vampire |url=http://www.navy.gov.au/w/images/Navy_News-May-28-1965.pdf |newspaper=Navy News |date=28 May 1965 |page=5 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110321000717/http://www.navy.gov.au/w/images/Navy_News-May-28-1965.pdf |archivedate=21 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> ''Vampire'' escorted the aircraft carrier {{HMAS|Melbourne|R21|6}} during SEATO Exercise Seahorse.<ref name=Bastock322/> During early June, ''Vampire'' accompanied the troop transport {{HMAS|Sydney|R17|6}} for parts of the latter's first transport voyage to Vietnam.<ref name=NottPayne169>Nott & Payne, ''The Vung Tau Ferry'', p. 169</ref> The ship's fifth Far East deployment was concluded when she reached Sydney on 22 June.<ref name=Bastock322/> On 20 December, the [[Cremation|ashes]] of Vice Admiral [[Hastings Harrington|Sir Hastings Harrington]] were scattered from ''Vampire'' off the coast of Sydney.<ref name=Bastock322/>
''Vampire'' was sent on her sixth Far East deployment in March 1966.<ref name=Cassells148/><ref name=Bastock322/> In late April, ''Vampire'' was temporarily withdrawn from Strategic Reserve service to escort ''Sydney'' on her third Vietnam voyage: the destroyer returned to Hong Kong on 9 May.<ref name=NottPayne170>Nott & Payne, ''The Vung Tau Ferry'', p. 170</ref> During late May and early June, ''Vampire'' participated in SEATO Exercise Sea Imp.<ref name=Bastock322/> On 10 June 1966, ''Vampire'' collided with the Danish merchant ship ''Emilie Maersk'' on the [[Chao Phraya River]]; the destroyer received only minor damage, and was repaired in Singapore.<ref name=Bastock322/> From July to August, the destroyer was assigned to [[Tawau]] to protect the region from Indonesian aggression during the Confrontation.<ref name=Bastock322/> This primarily consisted of using her radar to detect approaching vessels and coordinate interception efforts, although ''Vampire'' was called on to provide [[Naval gunfire support|fire support]] for Commonwealth land forces on two occasions.<ref name=Shaw6/> The ship returned to Sydney on 13 August.<ref name=Bastock323>Bastock, ''Australia's Ships of War'', p. 323</ref>
On 4 January 1967, ''Vampire'' sailed for her seventh FESR tour.<ref name=Bastock323/> The destroyer provided assistance to the grounded freighter ''Mata Thevi'' in February, and from April until May, accompanied ''Sydney'' on the latter's fifth and sixth troop transport voyages.<ref name=Bastock323/><ref name=NottPayne171>Nott & Payne, ''The Vung Tau Ferry'', p. 171</ref> During the voyage back to Australia in late August and early September, ''Vampire'' made port visits in Indonesia; the first RAN ship to do so after the Confrontation's end.<ref name=Bastock323/> On arrival in Sydney, the destroyer was docked for a six-month refit.<ref name=Bastock323/> In July 1968, ''Vampire'' and other vessels of the RAN were involved in training exercises with the [[Royal New Zealand Navy]].<ref name=Bastock323/> The destroyer visited Indonesia again in September, then served as review ship during a ceremonial fleet entry into Sydney Harbour: for this role, several weapons, including one of the three 4.5-inch turrets, were temporarily removed.<ref name=Bastock323/>
On 23 March 1969, ''Vampire'' returned to the Far East.<ref name=Bastock323/> On 14 May 1969, the destroyer met ''Sydney'' off Singapore, and escorted the troopship to [[V≈©ng T√†u]] on the former aircraft carrier's fourteenth Vietnam voyage.<ref name=NottPayne174>Nott & Payne, ''The Vung Tau Ferry'', p. 174</ref> The destroyer returned to Australian waters in October.<ref name=Bastock323/> On 16 April 1970, ''Vampire'' joined a fleet of 45 naval ships from 13 nations to perform a ceremonial entry into Sydney Harbour as part of the first [[Australian Bicentenary]], celebrating the discovery and claiming of the east coast of Australia by [[James Cook]].<ref>Lind, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', pp. 274‚Äì275</ref>
===Refit (1970‚Äì1972)=== In June 1970, ''Vampire'' was handed over to [[Williamstown Naval Dockyard]] for a $US10 million modernisation.<ref name=Cassells148/> The modernisation consisted of over 2,000 upgrades and modifications.<ref name=Shaw7/> The sensor suite, including fire control systems, air radar, and surface radar, was updated.<ref name=Shaw7/> The destroyer's armament was refurbished, with the main gun turrets rebuilt and the Bofors reconditioned, although the torpedo pentad mount was removed.<ref name=Shaw7/> The superstructure was rebuilt, with the primary aim to enclose the open bridge area, along with modernisation of the ship's galleys and installation of more air conditioning.<ref name=Shaw7/><ref name=Bastock323/> Redesigned masts and funnel cowlings were fitted.<ref name=Bastock323/> ''Vampire'' reentered active service on 4 March 1972.<ref name=Cassells148/>
===1972‚Äì1986=== In October 1972, ''Vampire'' was deployed to Singapore for four months as part of the [[ANZUK]] force: the first ''Daring'' class destroyer assigned to the force.<ref name=Bastock323/> She was temporarily withdrawn in November to accompany ''Sydney'' on her twenty-fifth and final voyage to V≈©ng T√†u.<ref name=NottPayne178>Nott & Payne, ''The Vung Tau Ferry'', p. 178</ref> ''Vampire'' returned to Sydney on 1 March 1973.<ref name=Cassells148/> In April, the destroyer sailed to [[Apia]], Samoa for the [[South Pacific Forum]].<ref>Bastock, ''Australia's Ships of War'', p. 323-4</ref> In September, the destroyer was part of a multinational training exercise off New Zealand, then returned to Sydney and was present for the opening of the [[Sydney Opera House]] on 20 October.<ref name=Bastock324>Bastock, ''Australia's Ships of War'', p. 324</ref>
''Vampire'' began 1974 by participating in a joint Australia-Indonesia military exercise, before sailing to the Coral Sea in June to participate in [[Exercise Kangaroo]] I.<ref name=Cassells148/> In September 1974, the ship entered Garden Island Dockyard for an eight-month refit.<ref name=Cassells148/>
On 22 August 1975, ''Vampire'', sister ship {{HMAS|Vendetta|D08|6}}, and the supply ship {{HMAS|Supply|AO 195|6}} were prepositioned in Darwin following tensions between Indonesia and the former Portuguese colony of East Timor (which cumulated in the Indonesian [[Indonesian invasion of East Timor|invasion]] in December).<ref name=Cassells148/><ref name=Jones231>Jones, in Stevens, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', p. 231</ref> The ships were to evacuate Australian citizens and Timorese refugees if needed, but this did not eventuate.<ref name=Cassells148/><ref name=Jones231/> On 21 September, the destroyer left Darwin for a five-month Strategic Reserve deployment.<ref name=Cassells148/> During her fifth deployment, which ended with her return to Sydney on 18 February 1976, ''Vampire'' joined training exercises with United States Navy ships in the China Sea, and visited sixteen ports in six countries for diplomatic and goodwill purposes.<ref name=Cassells148/> On 31 May 1976, ''Vampire'' and the destroyer escort {{HMAS|Stuart|DE 48|6}} departed Sydney Harbour for the United States.<ref name=Cassells148/> The two ships, along with the destroyer {{HMAS|Hobart|D 39|6}}, visited ports along the west coast of the United States as the RAN representatives during the [[United States Bicentennial]]: ''Vampire'' visited [[Long Beach, California]] and [[Seattle, Washington]].<ref>Cassells, ''The Destroyers'', pp. 148‚Äì149</ref> ''Vampire'' returned to Sydney on 6 August, but departed seven days later to participate in exercises in South East Asia.<ref name=Cassells149>Cassells, ''The Destroyers'', p. 149</ref>
During the visit of [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]] and [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Prince Phillip]] to Australia in March 1977, ''Vampire'' was assigned as the escort to [[HMY Britannia|Her Majesty's Yacht ''Britannia'']].<ref name=Cassells149/> ''Vampire'' met ''Britannia'' on 11 March, and accompanied the royal yacht to Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, and Fremantle.<ref name=Cassells149/> Between April and July 1977, ''Vampire'' was involved in two rescue missions and three fleet training exercises.<ref name=Cassells149/> On 5 September, ''Vampire'' left Sydney as "part of the RAN contribution to Queen Elizabeth's Silver Jubilee."<ref name=Cassells149/> The destroyer returned on 18 October.<ref name=Cassells149/> At the end of 1977, ''Vampire'' participated in Exercise Compass 77, held off Sri Lanka.<ref name=Cassells149/> The destroyer was primarily involved in training exercises during 1978 and 1979.<ref name=Cassells149/>
In April 1979, it was announced that ''Vampire'' would be converted into a training ship.<ref name=Cassells149/> This refit was carried out from 21 January to 18 April 1980, and included the removal of the destroyer's M22 fire control radars, LW-02 air search radar, Limbo anti-submarine mortar, and twin Bofors mounts, and the installation of a training classroom where the Limbo previously resided.<ref name=Cassells149/><ref>Shaw, ''HMAS Vampire'', pgs. 8, 10</ref> Following the conversion, ''Vampire'' was assigned to the RAN training squadron, where she joined {{HMAS|Jervis Bay|GT 203|6}}.<ref name=Cassells149/> On 13 May, ''Vampire'' and ''Jervis Bay'' were ordered to the Solomon Islands to observe the splashdown of China's first intercontinental ballistic missile test-firing.<ref name=Lind296>Lind, ''The Royal Australian Navy'', p. 296</ref> The ICBM landed north-west of Fiji, and was observed by both the two Australian ships and a fleet of 18 warships from the [[People's Liberation Army Navy]].<ref name=Lind296/> On 6 November 1980, the two ships joined the patrol boats {{HMAS|Aware|P 91|2}} and {{HMAS|Ardent|P 87|2}} to perform a ceremonial entry into Darwin as part of the city's Navy Week.<ref name=Cassells149/>
==Decommissioning and preservation== On 25 June 1986, ''Vampire'' left active service.<ref name=Cassells149/> She was decommissioned on 13 August 1986, having spent 27 years in service, and travelled {{convert|808026|nmi|km}}.<ref name=brooke/> She was later presented to the [[Australian National Maritime Museum]] for preservation as a [[museum ship]]: on loan from 1990 to 1997, then transferred outright in 1997.<ref>Shaw, ''HMAS Vampire'', p. 13</ref> ''Vampire'' is the largest museum piece on display in Australia.<ref name=ShawHist19/> The ship is also used for training RAN divers in hull clearance.<ref name=ShawHist19/> In 1994, two disabled twin Bofors mounts were returned to the destroyer, replacing those removed in 1980.<ref name=Shaw10/> On 9 April 1997, permission was granted for ''Vampire'' to fly the [[Australian White Ensign]], despite not being a commissioned warship.<ref>Shaw, ''HMAS Vampire'', p. 22</ref>
The destroyer is towed to {{HMAS|Kuttabul|naval base|6}} every five years for maintenance and cleaning.<ref name=ShawHist19>Shaw, ''Historic RAN ships in Australia'', p. 19</ref> During a docking in October 2006, rumours spread among RAN personnel that ''Vampire'' would be refitted and returned to active service.<ref name=brooke>Brooke, ''Destroyer revamped''</ref> During the same refit, a fire broke out in the ship's boiler room.<ref name=DTfire>Pride of naval museum catches fire, ''The Daily Telegraph''</ref> Nobody was injured, and no irreparable damage was caused.<ref name=DTfire/>
An overhaul of the RAN [[battle honour]]s system completed in March 2009 saw ''Vampire'' retroactively honoured for her service in the Strategic Reserve between 1964 and 1966‚Äîthe time of the [[Indonesia-Malaysia Confrontation]].<ref name=newhonours>{{cite news |url=http://www.navy.gov.au/Navy_Marks_109th_Birthday_With_Historic_Changes_To_Battle_Honours |title=Navy Marks 109th Birthday With Historic Changes To Battle Honours |date=1 March 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613184920/http://www.navy.gov.au/Navy_Marks_109th_Birthday_With_Historic_Changes_To_Battle_Honours |archivedate=13 June 2011 |publisher=Royal Australian Navy |accessdate=23 December 2012}}</ref><ref name=honourslist>{{cite web |url=http://www.navy.gov.au/w/images/Units_entitlement_list.pdf |title=Royal Australian Navy Ship/Unit Battle Honours |date=1 March 2010 |publisher=Royal Australian Navy |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614064156/http://www.navy.gov.au/w/images/Units_entitlement_list.pdf |archivedate=14 June 2011 |accessdate=23 December 2012}}</ref> Any future ships named HMAS ''Vampire'' will carry the battle honour "Malaysia 1964‚Äì66" in addition to the honours earned by [[HMAS Vampire (D68)|the previous HMAS ''Vampire'']].<ref name=honourslist/>
In November 2015, the warship was moved to the new Warships Pavilion 'Action Stations' at the [[Australian National Maritime Museum]] alongside [[HMAS Onslow]] and [[HMAS Advance]].
